name: Whale Shark
fact: Largest fish alive; feeds mostly on plankton despite its massive size.

name: Great White Shark
fact: Can detect a single drop of blood in 25 gallons of water.

name: Tiger Shark
fact: Nicknamed the 'garbage can of the sea'—it’ll eat anything, from birds to car plates.

name: Hammerhead Shark
fact: That head shape gives it nearly 360° vision and superb sensory accuracy.

name: Blacktip Reef Shark
fact: Named for the black markings on its fins; often seen near shallow coral reefs.

name: Nurse Shark
fact: Nocturnal bottom dweller that sucks up prey like a vacuum with its strong mouth.

name: Basking Shark
fact: The second-largest fish in the ocean, but entirely harmless to humans.

name: Dogfish Shark
fact: Small but fierce; known for pack-hunting tactics unusual for sharks.

name: Cookiecutter Shark
fact: Takes perfectly round 'cookie' bites out of whales, dolphins, and submarines.

name: Goblin Shark
fact: A deep-sea predator with a jaw that shoots forward like a spring-loaded trap.

name: Sawshark
fact: Has a chainsaw-like snout lined with sharp teeth used to slash through schools of fish.

name: Horn Shark
fact: Has blunt horns on its head and crushes shellfish with its powerful jaws.

name: Blue Whale
fact: The largest animal to ever exist—its tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant.

name: Humpback Whale
fact: Their haunting songs travel for hundreds of miles through the ocean.

name: Orca
fact: Apex predators with family pods that each have their own language and hunting techniques.

name: Sperm Whale
fact: Has the largest brain of any animal and can dive over 3,000 feet deep for over an hour.

name: Beluga
fact: Nicknamed the 'canary of the sea' for their playful and musical vocalizations.

name: Narwhal
fact: Their tusk is actually a giant sensory tooth that can detect changes in water pressure and temperature.

name: Bottlenose Dolphin
fact: One of the smartest animals on Earth—uses tools, names, and even jokes to communicate.

name: Indo-Pacific Humpbacked Dolphin
fact: Born gray but turns pink as it matures; thrives in coastal tropical waters.

name: Pacific White-Sided Dolphin
fact: Known as the 'smiling dolphin' for its permanent grin and playful leaps.

name: Vaquita
fact: The world’s rarest marine mammal—fewer than 10 remain in the wild.

name: Flamboyant Cuttlefish
fact: Walks across the seafloor flashing psychedelic colors to warn predators it’s toxic.

name: Giant Cuttlefish
fact: Males put on stunning color displays to impress mates or fool rivals.

name: Blue-ringed Octopus
fact: Tiny but deadly—its venom can kill 26 humans within minutes, and there’s no known antidote.

name: Giant Pacific Octopus
fact: Can open jars, recognize humans, and grow larger than a full-grown human male.

name: Dumbo Octopus
fact: Named for its ear-like fins; lives deeper than any other known octopus species.

name: Blanket Octopus
fact: Females can be six feet long while males stay the size of a walnut—one of the ocean’s wildest gender gaps.

name: Mimic Octopus
fact: Can impersonate over 15 other sea creatures, including lionfish, sea snakes, and flatfish.

name: Giant Squid
fact: Possesses eyes the size of dinner plates; long believed to be the origin of kraken myths.

name: Giant Oarfish
fact: Longest bony fish on Earth; its sightings near shore often spark earthquake legends in Japan.

name: Sunfish
fact: Can weigh over two tons but mostly just floats near the surface like a lazy solar panel.

name: Lanternfish
fact: One of the most abundant vertebrates on Earth; lights up the ocean with bioluminescent photophores.

name: Anglerfish
fact: Females have glowing lures and tiny parasitic males that fuse into their bodies permanently.

name: Footballfish
fact: Another anglerfish cousin—its glowing lure can dangle up to a third of its body length.

name: Psychedelic Frogfish
fact: Crawls instead of swims, patterned like coral, and changes color faster than a mood ring.

name: Hairy Frogfish
fact: Covers itself in whisker-like spines and uses a lure on its head to ambush prey.

name: Barreleye
fact: Has a transparent head and rotating tubular eyes that can look straight up through its own skull.

name: Mantis Shrimp
fact: Punches faster than a bullet, shattering glass and stunning prey with shockwaves.

name: False Cleanerfish
fact: Pretends to clean other fish—then bites off their scales and mucus.

name: Lobster
fact: Can live for over 100 years and actually grows stronger with age thanks to its regenerative molting.

name: Snipe Eel
fact: Has a beak-like mouth that can’t fully close, but it uses it to snag tiny shrimp in midwater.

name: Moray Eel
fact: Has a second set of jaws in its throat that shoots forward to grab prey like a sci-fi monster.

name: Ribbon Eel
fact: Starts life male, turns female later; its vibrant blue and yellow body looks like an underwater ribbon.

name: Sea Slug
fact: Some species can photosynthesize by stealing chloroplasts from the algae they eat.

name: Sea Pig
fact: A walking sea cucumber that lives in deep-sea mud and hoovers up decaying whale goo.

name: Sea Bunny
fact: Tiny and fuzzy-looking sea slug that resembles a rabbit—adorable but mildly toxic.

name: Immortal Jellyfish
fact: Can revert to its juvenile form after adulthood, making it biologically immortal (the Benjamin Button of the sea).

name: Moon Jellyfish
fact: Translucent and hypnotic—moves by pulsing gently through the current like a living lava lamp.

name: Egg-Yolk Jellyfish
fact: Bright yellow center looks like a sunny-side-up egg; tentacles can reach 20 feet long.

name: Portuguese Man o' War
fact: Not one animal, but a colony of organisms working together to sting everything in sight.

name: Pacific Sea Nettle
fact: Drifts in massive jellyfish blooms; its sting can feel like touching a live wire.

name: Sea Cucumber
fact: When threatened, it can eject its own organs to distract predators and later regrow them.

name: Giant Isopod
fact: Deep-sea relative of the pill bug; looks like a huge armored roach but just wants to nap forever.

name: Leatherback Sea Turtle
fact: Largest turtle on Earth—can dive deeper than 4,000 feet and migrate thousands of miles.

name: Manta Ray
fact: Graceful ocean gliders that often perform somersaults while feeding on plankton.

name: Cownose Ray
fact: Moves in massive migrating schools; named for its cute, cow-shaped snout.

name: Sawfish
fact: Endangered species with a saw-like snout used for hunting and defense.

name: Skate
fact: Flat-bodied relatives of rays with rougher skin and egg cases known as 'mermaid’s purses'.

name: California Sea Lion
fact: Smart, playful, and loud—known for surfing waves and stealing fish from docks.

name: Harbor Seal
fact: Quiet, curious sea dogs that can sleep underwater for up to 30 minutes.

name: Elephant Seal
fact: Huge blubbery brawlers that fight each other for dominance with roaring duels.

name: Swordfish
fact: Uses its long bill to slash through schools of fish at high speeds.

name: Clownfish
fact: Lives in anemones for protection and keeps them clean—teamwork at its cutest.

name: Horseshoe Crab
fact: Older than dinosaurs; its blue blood is used in medical testing to detect bacterial contamination.

name: Hermit Crab
fact: Lives inside discarded shells; will fight or barter for a better one when it outgrows the old.

name: Japanese Spider Crab
fact: Largest arthropod on Earth with legs spanning up to 12 feet.

name: Seahorse
fact: Males carry and give birth to the babies—take that, patriarchy.

name: Giant Clam
fact: Can weigh over 500 pounds and live more than a century, filtering plankton from coral reefs.

name: Yeti Crab
fact: Discovered near hydrothermal vents—covered in silky white hair it uses to farm bacteria for food.

name: Goblin Shark
fact: Sometimes called a living fossil—its jaw launches forward like a monster movie jump-scare.

name: Tripod Fish
fact: Balances on long fins like stilts on the seafloor, facing into the current waiting for food to drift by.

name: Zombie Worm
fact: Lives off the bones of dead whales using symbiotic bacteria to digest fat and marrow.

name: Black Dragonfish
fact: A deep-sea predator that glows red—a color most fish can’t even see.

name: Vampire Squid
fact: Lives where almost nothing else can, fluttering its cloak-like webbing in pitch darkness.

name: Pelican Eel
fact: Has a massive expandable mouth shaped like a pelican’s beak that can engulf prey its own size.

name: Stargazer Fish
fact: Buries itself in sand with only its eyes and mouth showing—then ambushes prey from below.

name: Fangtooth Fish
fact: Has the largest teeth-to-body ratio of any fish in the ocean and a permanent scowl.

name: Gulper Eel
fact: Its balloon-like mouth can stretch wide enough to swallow creatures larger than itself.

name: Firefly Squid
fact: Small but spectacular—thousands light up Japan’s Toyama Bay each year in glowing blue waves.

name: Hydrothermal Vent Snail
fact: Builds an iron sulfide shell that makes it one of the only animals with armor made of metal.

name: Dumbo Octopus
fact: Flaps ear-like fins to hover through the deep like a tiny ghost elephant.

name: Pink See-Through Fantasia
fact: A transparent sea cucumber that glows pink and reveals its organs while drifting midwater.

name: Sea Spider
fact: Not actually a spider, but close enough to be nightmare fuel—it pumps blood with its legs instead of a heart.

name: Giant Tube Worm
fact: Thrives in boiling vent water with no mouth or stomach—relies entirely on symbiotic bacteria for survival.

name: Axolotl
fact: A salamander that never grows up—stays in its larval stage forever and can regrow its limbs, spine, and even parts of its brain.

name: Coelacanth
fact: Thought extinct for 65 million years until a fisherman caught one in 1938—proof that time travel is real and scaly.

name: Mimic Seahorse
fact: A tiny master of disguise that mirrors coral textures so perfectly it’s nearly invisible.

name: Pistol Shrimp
fact: Snaps its claw so fast it creates a bubble that hits 200 decibels and momentarily reaches the temperature of the sun.

name: Leaf Sheep
fact: A sea slug that looks like a tiny cartoon sheep and literally photosynthesizes sunlight to live.

name: Bobbit Worm
fact: An ambush predator that can grow 10 feet long, slicing fish in half with jaws faster than a mousetrap.

name: Glaucus Atlanticus (Blue Dragon)
fact: A blue sea slug that drifts upside down on the ocean’s surface and steals venom from the Portuguese Man o’ War.

name: Sailfish
fact: Hunts in coordinated packs, flashing its sail-like dorsal fin to confuse prey while sprinting 68 mph underwater.

name: Sarcastic Fringehead
fact: Defends its burrow by pressing its massive colorful mouth against intruders like a deranged kiss.

name: Sea Angel
fact: A transparent, winged snail that flaps through polar waters like a glass butterfly—hauntingly beautiful.

name: Box Jellyfish
fact: One of the most venomous creatures on Earth; its sting can cause heart failure in under five minutes.

name: Stonefish
fact: Blends in perfectly with rocks and has venomous spines capable of killing a human in hours.

name: Cone Snail
fact: Pretty, patterned, and extremely deadly—it harpoons prey with a venomous tooth called a radula.

name: Greenland Shark
fact: Can live over 500 years and swims so slowly it’s basically the ocean’s ancient cryptid grandpa.

name: Frilled Shark
fact: Primitive species with 300 needle teeth that hasn’t changed in 80 million years—essentially a prehistoric eel.

name: Tardigrade
fact: Microscopic water bear that survives radiation, boiling water, and space itself—unkillable and unbothered.

name: Sea Pen
fact: Colonial coral animal shaped like a quill pen that glows with gentle bioluminescence when disturbed.

name: Salp
fact: Gelatinous barrel creature that drifts in chains and filters carbon, quietly helping regulate Earth’s climate.

name: Crown-of-Thorns Starfish
fact: Massive spiny starfish that feeds on coral; outbreaks can devastate reefs but are part of natural cycles.

name: Feather Star
fact: Looks like a floating flower but is actually an ancient echinoderm that swims by waving feathery arms.

name: Lion’s Mane Jellyfish
fact: Largest jellyfish in the world—tentacles can stretch over 100 feet long, rivaling blue whales in size.

name: Ghost Pipefish
fact: Transparent and delicate; hovers upside down in seagrass pretending to be part of the plant.

name: Sea Walnut
fact: A comb jelly that sparkles with rainbow light when it moves—basically an underwater rave organism.

name: Pangolin Shark (Chlamydoselachus angustidens)
fact: A rarely-seen relic of evolution with overlapping armor-like scales and a mouth full of hook teeth.

name: Sea Toad (Coffinfish)
fact: Pouts adorably while lurking on the seafloor and can inflate itself into a round pink balloon when threatened.

name: Colossal Squid
fact: Bigger, thicker, and heavier than the giant squid—with hooks on its tentacles instead of suckers.

name: Glass Octopus
fact: Almost completely transparent except for its eyes and digestive organs—like a floating ghost.

name: Deep-Sea Hatchetfish
fact: Has mirror-plated sides that reflect light, rendering it nearly invisible in the water column.

name: Ribbon Worm
fact: Shoots out a long, sticky proboscis that looks like a glowing lasso to catch prey.

name: Sea Urchin
fact: Spiny ecosystem engineers that graze on algae and can live for centuries.

name: Archerfish
fact: Spits jets of water to knock insects out of the air—adjusts for refraction like a built-in physicist.
